;香港医院管理局应将专业工程师的人数增加一倍，以监督医疗设备工程一个专家小组建议，由承包商自行维护和维修设施。

;

;当局周三还誓言要采取法律行动，追究承包商因涉嫌未能达到维修和维护标准而承担的责任，在今年早些时候发生了一系列涉及坠落物体的事件之后。由专家组处理的一项审查是由 2 月份在一家公立医院落下的手术灯引发的。

;

;“我们过去常常依靠承包商对高风险医疗设备进行维护工作 [没有生物医学工程师的监督]，但这些事件让我们意识到加强监督的重要性，”管理局行政总裁高百星博士说。

;

;香港医院应该使用技术来检查设施, 增加检查”

;

;柯还表示，目前每三年检查一次建筑物的做法并不理想。 “内部工作人员应该接管工作，并根据建筑物的年龄和状况进行更频繁的检查，”他说。

;

;邮报已经联系了负责维护建筑物的公司 Getinge早期事件中心的手术灯，以征求意见。

;

;由测量、工程和企业传播等领域的专家组成的工作组在经过三个月的审查后提供了一份包含 23 条建议的清单

;

;香港医院管理局承认老化设施维修困难

;

;

;

;委员会主席温文仪表示，管理局的生物医学工程师人数应增加一倍，以满足承包商监督设备工程的巨大需求。

;

;目前有 15 名生物医学工程师为当局工作。

;

;万说，43 家公立医院每年进行约 351,000 例维修。

;

;“生物医学工程师全神贯注于设备采购，而无暇监督[承包商]的维修和维护工作，这并不理想。”

;

;他建议进一步集中采购工作和主要维护合同在当局总部，让工程师专注于监督任务并接受相关培训。

;

;Wan 将一连串事件与建筑物和设施老化以及大流行期间定期维护中断联系起来, 并补充说，医院亦应妥善记录设备的使用手册，以协助监督工作。

;

;另一方面，委员会建议与设备工作分开的一般楼宇维修工作，应由内部处理，不依赖

;

;Wan 表示，当局医院共有约 740 名设施管理人员，他们应该参与大楼维修工程，理由是他们“拥有更强的主人翁意识”。< /p>;

;香港当局呼吁以医院坠物为警钟

;

;“他们应密切留意容易漏水的地方，这会增加风险的混凝土剥落。他们还应该经常检查高风险地方，把医院当作自己的家。”

;

;当局管理的300座建筑物中，有一半以上是30多年前竣工的。一些建筑物的历史超过 85 年。

;

;Wan 补充说，与外部承包商相比，内部设施工作人员会发现更容易适应维护计划。

;

;但 Ko 说考虑到每个病例的独特性，将不会成为检查易受攻击设施的频率的硬性指标。

;

;他说，每家医院都将设立一个安全委员会，以监督维修和保养

;

;香港医院护士因配药器故障而触电受伤

;

;注意到在短期内增加生物医学工程师的数量存在困难Ko 表示，技术将在未来一段时间内用于提高检测结构缺陷的效率。

;

;该机构的战略和规划总监程伟权博士表示，红外线扫描仪和湿度计是正在开发的工具之一用于辅助常规检查方法。

;

;当局正与理工大学合作，测试先进传感器和雷达在容易漏水的区域（包括厨房和洗手间）的应用，以促进及早发现混凝土剥落

;

;同时，当局还将加强内部报告和公开披露机制，要求根据新指南向管理层报告每起事件，并评估是否需要公开披露。

;中国应通过区域贸易协定和离岸贸易进一步吸引人们对使用人民币日益增长的兴趣根据中国银行的一份报告，随着北京方面以“有序”的方式增加人民币在全球的使用。

;

;15 国区域全面经济伙伴关系协定 (RCEP) 的成员占根据该银行周二发布的 2022 年人民币国际化白皮书，去年中国以人民币计价的汇款占 18.9%，而 2021 年为 15.9%，2020 年仅为 7.1%。

;

;它还强烈希望在中国支持的 RCEP 中扩大人民币的跨境使用，该 RCEP 涉及东南亚国家联盟（东盟）的 10 个成员国，加上中国、韩国、新西兰、澳大利亚和日本，它补充说.

;

;超过 90% 的国内外企业表示，他们认为，当主要货币之间的流动性受到冲击时，他们认为在跨境支付中“强烈”使用人民币可以在亚太地区稳定下来，国有银行调查显示。

;

;“2022年美联储继续加息，美元流动性收紧，人民币融资对境外市场主体的吸引力上升， ”报告称。

;

;“78.6%的受访境外工商企业表示，当美元、欧元等国际货币流动性相对紧张时，他们会选择人民币作为新的融资币种的选择，这个比例比2021年的调查结果提高了7.4个百分点。”

;

;该调查于1月30日至2月27日进行，收集了3600名国内外受访者的数据和反馈。工商企业、境外金融机构82家。它还使用了来自全球金融信息系统 Swift 的数据。

;

;近 80% 的人还表示，人民币在 10 年内的国际地位将不低于英镑和日元，尽管 79.8%百分比数字略低于 2021 年的 81% 和 2020 年的 80.2%。

;

;哪 8 个国家更多地使用人民币，这将如何影响美元？

;

;承认去年俄罗斯人民币交易的增长，中国银行看到了非洲离岸人民币交易的潜力，强调赞比亚、南非、安哥拉、吉布提和毛里求斯的中国金融机构可以考虑提供人民币存、贷和汇款服务。

;

;中国银行表示，在东亚的离岸人民币中心中，2022 年韩国的人民币存款余额同比下降 4.8% 至 17.8 亿美元。

;

;报告补充说，与 2021 年相比，韩国以人民币计价的汇款和支付总额增长了 14.4%。

;

;增加尚未完全可兑换的人民币在全球的使用。

;

;世界第二大经济体和出口大国继续严格控制跨境资金流动并管理人民币兑换

;

;国家外汇管理局副局长陆磊表示，要在国家对外开放的过程中创造更多的应用场景，并表示要加强其在区域协定中的使用。

;< p>;他表示，中国经济的稳定性和货币政策的审慎性是推动人民币“有序”国际化的重要基本面因素。

;

;“在有效防控的前提下风险，我们要继续提高外国投资者投资国内金融市场的便利化水平，畅通人民币交易渠道，提高境外实体持有人民币的意愿，”卢在最新一期的《金融时报》中写道。本周出版的《清华金融评论》。

;来自科技、银行、时尚和制造行业的 CEO 进行的一长串类似访问表明，西方主要企业对世界第二大经济体感兴趣。中国最大的经济体渴望在重新开放后重新参与。

;3 月，Busch 加入了苹果公司的蒂姆库克、沙特阿美公司的阿明等众多首席执行官的行列H Nasser 和 Mercedes-Benz 的 Ola Källenius 在北京备受瞩目的中国发展高层论坛上投下了对中国市场的信任票，尽管对该国在经济改革和地缘政治紧张局势方面取得的进展的担忧挥之不去。

;北京认为美国正在利用国际法作为挑衅和感觉的“掩护”据中国大陆观察人士称，中国“别无选择”，只能在台湾海峡拦截美国军舰。

;

;但美国海事法专家表示，中国的行动有“可能发生冲突”的风险，这表明北京无视国际惯例。

;

;6 月 3 日，一艘中国人民解放军 (PLA) 军舰在加美联合穿越台湾海峡的行动中驶近美国驱逐舰 137 米（150 码）以内，五角大楼说。

;

;美国官员指责解放军进行了“不安全和不专业”的演习，并警告说中国违反了有关安全通行的国际海事法，并增加了军事误判的风险。

;

;面对美国的挑衅，中国外交部称这次演习“合法”、“正当”，指责华盛顿在台海“挑起事端”。

;

;事件恰逢美国发布北京国防智库“南海战略态势探测倡议”的一项分析认为，根据国际法，中国有权拦截驶经海峡的美国军舰。

;

;中国论文指责加拿大媒体炒作解放军舰船“非常可怕”的举动

;

;美国军队长期以来一直引用“无害通过”的法律来捍卫他们通过台湾海峡和南中国海等敏感区域的航行。

;

;但该智库认为，根据《联合国海洋法公约》(UNCLOS) 第 25 条，中国等沿海国家有权决定什么是“无害通过”。

;

;“公约或一般国际法中从来没有不受限制的航行权，”它的分析写道。 “美国军舰可以行使无害通过权，但同时必须尊重沿海国对无害通过权的判断。”

;

;但美中外交分析人士对这种解读提出质疑。

;

;“根据国际法，无害通过仅在一个国家的 12 海里 [22 公里] 领海内相关，”战略与国际战略中心亚洲海事透明度倡议主任格雷戈里波林说研究。

;

;他说，该海峡最窄处宽 130 公里（70 海里），“太宽了，在任何情况下都不能被视为领海”。

;

;山东师范大学海上安全研究中心主任马建英表示：“客观地说，美国军舰有权通过台湾海峡。”

;

;但在马建英看来，中方认为美国的航海演习是一种“欺负中国的战术”，派出自己的军舰是一种威慑未来通过的信号。

;

;“中国别无选择，”马说。 “它无法阻止美国军舰穿越台湾海峡，所以它必须派出自己的军舰。”

;

;大多数欧洲人希望在美中台湾战争中保持中立：研究

;

;长期以来，中国一直认为美国军舰穿越海峡是不必要的挑衅，是对其对台湾主权主张的挑战——北京认为台湾是一个叛变的省份，应该以武力收复

;

;在最近的事件发生后，中国人民解放军东部战区新闻发言人施毅大校立即表示，美国的行动正在破坏地区和平与稳定，并向“台独势力发出了错误信号” .

;

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:50:01 +0800 Democrats’ disastrous US debt ceiling deal snatches defeat from jaws of victoryhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3223234/democrats-disastrous-us-debt-ceiling-deal-snatches-defeat-jaws-victory?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 21:30;
;;

;有一个关于两党合作的可恶的美国政治神话，根据这个神话，痛苦的对手，伤痕累累通过战斗，找到共同点，携手并肩漫步到夕阳下。这主要是胡说八道。

;

;在 Appomattox 之后，尤利西斯·格兰特 (Ulysses S. Grant) 没有与罗伯特·李 (Robert E. Lee) 和解。富兰克林·罗斯福在大萧条期间没有与赫伯特·胡佛和解，约翰·肯尼迪在 1960 年大选后也没有与理查德·尼克松和解。人们确实听到了罗纳德·里根和蒂普·奥尼尔交换花言巧语的甜蜜回忆。但真正的奥尼尔在原则和政治上竭尽全力与里根抗争。

;

;美国总统乔拜登最近在犯下令人震惊的行为后赞扬了众议院议长凯文麦卡锡政治投降——在税收执法、社会计划、学生债务、环境等方面。

;

;最糟糕的是，拜登放弃了债务上限不应阻碍未来进步优先事项的原则。但我们被告知，一切都很好，因为拜登和麦卡锡一起解决了问题。

;

;但白宫和财政部至少有三种貌似合法、完全符合宪法的方式来化解假想的危机，而无需麦卡锡参与以及他越来越精神错乱的共和党核心小组。政府本可以铸造一枚高价值的铂金硬币并将其存放在美国联邦储备委员会，诉诸永远不会到期的统一债券，或发行溢价债券。

;

;相反，他们从战壕中走出来，挥舞着白旗，并以讨价还价的方式卖掉了他们要塞的钥匙——所有这些都是为了让围攻的军队消失几年。更糟糕的是，民主党人知道共和党军队内部分裂且叛变。拜登表明，当他正确地告诉他们，在他们第一次接近时迷路。

;

;但还有一个更大的事实，没有人愿意承认：共和党人的大炸弹总是哑弹。根据法律，财政部不能停止或优先支付。财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和她的前任们早就强调了这一点。

;

;即使你超过了“限度”，支票也必须发出。债务上限只会阻止财政部发行新债券。在最坏的情况下，美联储的财政部总账户将没有足够的资金来支付支票。

;

;到那时，美联储可能会发放信贷额度——透支——以确保付款得到兑现.无担保、无利息、隔夜透支不在债务上限范围内，并且可以说是一种合法的可能性。美联储自己的记录表明，此事将由其理事会决定。

;

;这个问题最终可能会在法庭上得到检验，但那又怎样？如果美联储如此决定，或者如果法院如此下令，其中一些财政部支票可能会反弹，成为对财政部的无担保债权。如果银行拒绝兑现，美联储需要多长时间才能恳求国会解决“危机”？我怀疑这种情况会在第二天开市前发生。

;

;如果违反债务上限真的有“灾难”的风险，那么责任应该归咎于那些决定大肆宣传的共和党人，并且他们几乎肯定会弃牌。如果与所有逻辑相反，他们选择了政治自杀，那么对民主党人来说就更好了。

;

;无论哪种方式，白宫都握有大炮，但它仍然投降了。拜登的顾问似乎并不特别在意所做的让步，而且至少有些人有充分的经济理由避免违约的后果。

;

;让我们来看看这种情况。假设麦卡锡的势力坚守，拜登不投降，美联储发放透支，政治僵局持续下去。即便如此，生活仍会正常进行，只是到期国债将以现金偿还，因为它们将不再展期。

;

;债券持有人可能不喜欢这样，他们可能会用现金购买别的东西。正如希拉里·克林顿在《纽约时报》中警告的那样，国际美元将会贬值，这意味着以国际美元为生的极少数精英将受到更大的打击。对于美国其他地区，这将类似于罗斯福于 1933 年暂停金本位制并推出新政。

;

;美国工业将变得更具竞争力，工业和制造业工作岗位将开始回归。尽管美元贬值是有代价的，但必须权衡利弊。此外，无论如何，美元都会走软。

;

;“灾难”情景从一开始就是荒谬的。这确实与民主党的性格有关。它会继续迎合大型金融机构，还是会被迫代表自己的选民和美国人民的利益？

;

;支持美国债务上限协议的主流共和党人欢迎理智的迹象

;

;如果拜登再次当选，国会民主党人将在2025年再次面临同样的选择。他们可以同意更多的让步，再次躲在“两党合作”的花言巧语背后，也可以最终拒绝屈服于勒索。

;

;如果拜登被击败呢？共和党人将在联邦计划、法规、税收和债务上限方面为所欲为。 This latest disgraceful episode has made such an outcome more likely. After all, who needs a Democratic Party that won't stand up for itself or its constituents?

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:50:01 +0800 Apple’s AirDrop in focus as China moves to restrict Wi-fi, Bluetooth file-sharing over ‘national security’ concernshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3223303/apples-airdrop-focus-china-moves-restrict-wi-fi-bluetooth-file-sharing-over-national-security?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 20:55;
;;

;China is planning to regulate file-sharing among nearby mobile devices for “national security” reasons, in a move expected to impact the use of such communication apps, such as Apple's AirDrop.

;

;According to a draft released by China's top internet watchdog, the new rules aim to limit the use of any “file transfer services that rely on Wi-fi, Bluetooth, and other information technologies to form networks instantly and communicate to other devices over a short-range”.

;

;The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) posted the draft regulation on its website on Tuesday as it launched a month-long public consultation on the matter.

;

;The CAC move is the latest in Beijing's drive to “safeguard national security”. File-sharing service AirDrop – which is available on iPhones and other Apple devices – was used during public demonstrations last winter against the mainland's strict zero-Covid restrictions, and also during anti-government protests in Hong Kong in 2019.

;

;Similar close-range wireless communication features launched in recent years by other companies include Files by Google and Fast Share on Google's Android operating service.

;

;Chinese phone makers Vivo, Xiaomi and Oppo also offer such file transfer services that are compatible among their own devices.

;

;The regulation says technology companies must undergo security assessment if they wish to include any features that could be used “for public expression and social mobilisation”. All users of such features must also sign up under their real names.

;

;According to Gao Fuping, a law professor at the East China University of Political Science and Law in Shanghai, the real-name registration requirement aims to “fill a loophole” in content control when it comes to network transmission services like AirDrop, even though China rolled out the real-name system for online activities a decade ago.

;

;“It is mainly about cybersecurity, and the core aim is to ensure all the information transmission can be traced in case problematic things happen,” Gao said.

;

;Launched in 2011, Apple's AirDrop feature has been a convenient tool to share files with nearby users over Wi-fi or Bluetooth, without the need to rely on an internet connection. Images can be shared anonymously and AirDrop only shows nearby phones under their chosen nicknames, with no way for the user to identify the sender.

;

;The draft regulation also stipulates that such “close-range mesh network” service providers “save relevant records” and report to internet regulators if they find any “illegal information” or “dissemination of harmful information”.

;

;However, it does not elaborate what kind of information might be considered illegal or harmful.

;

;Apple's iPhone commands a fifth of the mobile device market share in mainland China and around half of Hong Kong's, according to the latest data from tech market trackers CounterPoint Research.

;

;Last November, protests broke out in multiple Chinese cities over frustrations relating to the government's draconian zero-Covid policy of lockdowns, border closures, mass testing and strict quarantine. AirDrop was used then to share anti-government images, Western media reports said.

;

;Earlier that month, in an update to its operating system, Apple imposed a 10-minute time limit on exchanging AirDrop content via all iPhones sold in mainland China. This was seen as a move to prevent Chinese iPhone users from evading the country's strict web censorship.

;

;Although Apple did not explain why it made such a change, it came shortly after a protester – later nicknamed “bridge man” – unfurled two banners on a bridge in Beijing, calling for an end to the harsh Covid-19 policy and criticising the ruling Communist Party.

;

;While references to the protest were blocked by internet censors, photos were reportedly shared among the Chinese public via AirDrop.

;

;Also, during anti-government protests in Hong Kong in 2019, young activists used AirDrop to send out messages on the subway and in other public places, inviting the public to join the demonstrations.

;

;Angela Zhang, an associate professor of law at the University of Hong Kong, said the latest tightening measures from Beijing “collectively aim to strengthen the CAC's control over [internet] content and information dissemination”.

;

;But she also noted that the new rules were unlikely to have a significant impact on the tech industry as a whole, as they primarily appeared to target the AirDrop function.

;

;Apple's mainland China headquarters did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

;

;Beijing vows crackdown on 'hostile forces', stops short of mentioning protests

;

;The draft CAC rules also require technology companies to set “receiving off” as default for such features.

;

;Snapshot previews must also be disabled, unless users give consent. Current AirDrop settings allow users to be sent information deemed sensitive or explicit, though they can choose to accept or decline.

;

;In recent years, there have been calls for Big Tech companies like Apple to modify features like AirDrop to avoid their potential misuse, where offenders can easily harass users by sharing explicit images, which can be especially triggering for sexual assault survivors.

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:20:03 +0800 Europe’s No 2 chip maker STMicroelectronics to form US$3.2 billion semiconductor joint venture with China’s Sanan Optoelectronics in Chongqinghttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3223287/europes-no-2-chip-maker-stmicroelectronics-form-us32-billion-semiconductor-joint-venture-chinas?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 21:00;
;;

;STMicroelectronics (STM), Europe's second-largest chip maker by revenue, and Chinese firm Sanan Optoelectronics on Wednesday said they have agreed to form a US$3.2 billion semiconductor joint venture in the southwestern city of Chongqing, supporting rising domestic demand for silicon carbide (SiC) devices in the electric vehicle, industrial power and energy sectors.

;

;The deal involves the creation of a new 200-millimetre SiC device manufacturing operation that will start production in the fourth quarter of 2025, with anticipated full buildout in 2028.

;

;“China is moving fast towards electrification in automotive and industrial, and this is a market where ST is already well-established with many engaged customer programmes,” Jean-Marc Cherry, president and chief executive of STMicroelectronics, said in a statement released on Wednesday. “Creating a dedicated foundry with a key local partner is the most efficient way to serve the rising demand of our Chinese customers.”

;

;This new enterprise will be financed by contributions from STMicroelectronics and Sanan Optoelectronics, local government support and loans to the joint venture, according to the statement.

;

;In parallel, Sanan Optoelectronics will build and operate separately a new 200mm SiC substrate manufacturing facility to fulfil the joint venture's requirements, using its own SiC substrate process.

;

;One of the most important advanced ceramics in contemporary usage, SiC is a semiconductor base material consisting of silicon and carbon. Historically, manufacturers used SiC in high-temperature settings for devices such as bearings, heating machinery components, car brakes and even knife-sharpening tools.

;

;In recent years, SiC has become a force in the semiconductor industry.应用于金属氧化物半导体场效应晶体管、电源模块等芯片。 SiC devices are now widely used in electric car, rail transport, and wind and solar power applications.

;

;STMicroelectronics' new joint venture in Chongqing, a major manufacturing base in China, underscores the country's efforts to remain strong in “legacy semiconductors” – defined as chips made with 28-nanometre process technology or older – amid US trade sanctions that have restricted the mainland's access to advanced integrated circuits and chip-making equipment.

;

;Sanan Optoelectronics chief executive Simon Lin said the joint venture with STMicroelectronics is expected to become “a major driving force for the wide adoption of SiC devices on the Chinese market”.

;

;Completion of their manufacturing venture is subject to regulatory approvals, according to the statement.

;

;Switzerland-based STMicroelectronics, which has been operating in China for around four decades, has moved to deepen its ties to the world's second largest economy, despite the escalating tech war between Washington and Beijing.

;

;During his visit to China in December, company chief Chery expressed STMicroelectronics' commitment to China amid fast-growing demand for semiconductors in the country's vast electric vehicle market, according to a report by state-run newspaper Economic Daily that month.

;

;Sales of new energy vehicles in China nearly doubled to 6.9 million units last year, leading the world for eight consecutive years, according to the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers.

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:20:03 +0800 Chinese President Xi Jinping calls for greater efforts to fight desertification after climate change leads to spike in dust cloudshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3223297/chinese-president-xi-jinping-calls-greater-efforts-fight-desertification-after-climate-change-leads?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 21:00;
;;

;Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for a greater effort to tackle desertification as he warned the number of dust clouds hitting the north of the country had increased as a result of climate change.

;

;Xi made the comments during a tour of Inner Mongolia on Monday and Tuesday, saying the country had made remarkable progress in preventing and controlling desertification, but still faced major challenges.

;

;“In the past two years, the number of dusty weather incidents in northern China has increased due to the impact of climate change,” Xi said on Tuesday, according to state news agency Xinhua.

;

;While China's desertification control work had shown an “overall and accelerated improvement”, he warned large areas were still affected and urged officials to understand that it would need “long-term, arduous, repetitive and uncertain” efforts to tackle the problem.

;

;Asia climate woes mount as heat shatters May records

;

;In the first four months of 2023, there were 11 dust events in northern China – the highest number over the same period in the past decade, Jia Xiaolong, deputy director of the National Climate Centre, said earlier this year.

;

;Three of the incidents were classified as sandstorms, including one that happened between March 19 and 23 and was the third strongest storm recorded this century, affecting an area of over 4.85 million sq km (1.9 million sq miles), according to Xinhua.

;

;Another dust storm in early April swept more than 20 provinces and affected an area of 4.6 million sq km.

;

;A Chinese study – published in the peer-reviewed journal Advances in Atmospheric Sciences in May – found that Mongolia and China's largest desert, the Taklamakan in Xinjiang, were the two main sources of sand and dust in northern China.

;

;This spring it said dust and sand blowing across the border with Mongolia was responsible for 42 per cent of the dust concentration while the Taklamakan contributed 26 per cent.

;

;The study found that the intensified Mongolian cyclone and a cold front were the key factors for the dust events, carrying dust and sand southwards.

;

;Northern China has been affected by dust storms for decades, but the frequency and intensity of the events has decreased in recent years due to control works.

;

;China faces calls to expand its carbon emissions rights trading

;

;China implemented the Great Green Wall project in 1978, aiming to plant some 88 million acres of forests in a belt stretching across an area as wide as 4,800km by 1,500km (3,000 by 900 miles).

;

;The plan – officially known as the Three-North Shelterbelt Project – aims to increase forest cover in the region from 5 per cent in 1978 to 15 per cent by 2050, and had reached 13.6 per cent by 2019.

;

;Ma Jun, director of Beijing-based non-profit the Institute of Public and Environmental Affairs, said the frequency and intensity of dust events had been decreasing over the past two decades.

;

;“It's not only because of the implementation of the Great Green Wall project, but also other policies such as the Green for Grain programme,” he said.

;

;The Green for Grain programme, in which the government paid farmers to plant trees on their land to combat deforestation, was established in 1999.

;

;During his trip to Inner Mongolia, Xi said this decade would be critical for desert control efforts.

;

;“[We should] use 10 years to build the Three-North Shelterbelt Project into a fully functional and unbreakable green great wall and ecological security barrier in northern China,” Xi said.

;

;He also stressed the importance of improving the quality and stability of desert ecosystems.

;

;With key industries at stake, China and Mongolia team up to stop desertification

;

;Ma said China had learned lessons from its previous efforts to tackle desertification, and its experiences could be shared with other countries.

;

;“For example, there should be a combination of trees, shrubs and grasses … depending on the local ecology – rather than just planting trees,” he said.

;

;“China has some 2.5 million sq km under desertification, so the desertification control work is difficult and can't be relaxed.”

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:20:03 +0800 Hong Kong civil service chief appeals to staff to sign up as organ donors and give the gift of lifehttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3223306/hong-kong-civil-service-chief-appeals-staff-sign-organ-donors-and-give-gift-life?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 21:12;
;;

;Hong Kong authorities have appealed to more than 173,000 civil servants to sign up as organ donors after a surge in withdrawals from the register which the city leader said was a bid to “sabotage” the system.

;

;Secretary for the Civil Service Ingrid Yeung Ho Poi-yan appealed in a letter to government staff on Wednesday to register with the Centralised Organ Donation Register and to tell their families of their decision.

;

;The move came after health authorities spotted an “unusual rise” in the number of people applying to be taken off the register from last December, when the government revealed intent to establish a donation mechanism with mainland China.

;

;Officials said among the 5,785 withdrawal applications received over the last few months, more than 2,900 were found to be invalid as they were filed by people not on the register.

;

;Police have arrested four men for filing some withdrawal applications in the names of other people without consent.

;

;Yeung said in the letter, seen by the Post: “Over 2,000 patients and their families are waiting for organ donation every day in Hong Kong. Regretfully, many patients passed away before getting the right organ match and transplant.

;

;“It is therefore very important to secure active support for organ donation from the community at large with a view to bringing these patients the hope of a new life.

;

;“I earnestly invite colleagues to respond to the appeal by signing up at the Centralised Organ Donation Register and making known your wish to your family.”

;

;She also told civil service staff when she was at the then Health, Welfare and Food Bureau more than a decade ago, she was “deeply moved” by a mother's decision, although stricken with grief, to donate her son's organs after he was killed in a traffic accident.

;

;“While the success rate for organ transplant is very high in Hong Kong, we need to have such selfless and compassionate donors and family members in order to benefit the patients in need,” Yeung wrote.

;

;Hong Kong organ donation register hit by wave of withdrawal applications

;

;Secretary of Health Lo Chung-mau said during an event at the Legislative Council on Wednesday that many on the transplant waiting list were on the verge of life and death.

;

;He added he was distressed to see “a very small” number of people interfere with the organ donation register.

;

;About 5 per cent of Hong Kong's 7.4 million population – 370,000 people – have registered as donors and Lo said there was room for improvement.

;

;Legco president Andrew Leung Kwan-yuen added that spreading rumours about the organ donation programme was an act that displayed “ulterior motives and no conscience”.

;

;The four arrested in connection with the withdrawals, aged between 19 and 47, are alleged to have cancelled registrations, including those of government officials, lawmakers, artists and people that had already died.

;

;The force said at the time it had not ruled out further arrests.

;

;Police to target organ donation rumour mongers, Hong Kong health chief warns

;

;Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu said on Tuesday he was “concerned” about actions that appeared to be designed to sabotage the organ donation scheme.

;

;He added the behaviour reminded him of events during the 2019 anti-government protests and the city's “colour revolution”.

;

;“We must condemn these shameless acts. The government will also pursue their legal responsibilities,” Lee said.

;
